header.title: The Projection of the Astral Body

central_thesis: The astral body, an ethereal duplicate of the physical body and the true seat of consciousness, can be voluntarily projected from the physical form through specific psychological and physiological methods, primarily by influencing the subconscious Will through 'stress' and inducing physical 'incapacity,' thereby allowing conscious experience of the astral plane and interaction with subtler realities.

structure_content.summary: The author, Sylvan J. Muldoon, introduces the book by recounting his involuntary astral projections from age twelve. He asserts that conscious astral projection is a verifiable reality, emphasizing personal experience over objective proof. The text aims to provide practical methods for astral projection, which the author discovered through extensive experimentation, and critiques the lack of such practical guidance in existing occult literature.

Hereward Carrington, a collaborator, defines the astral body as the ethereal counterpart of the physical, a vehicle for the soul. He notes its withdrawal during sleep, trance, or anesthesia (involuntary projection) versus conscious, voluntary projection. The 'Silver Cord' links the two bodies, its severance leading to death. Carrington highlights Muldoon's unique contribution in providing detailed, first-hand accounts and practical 'how-to' information for conscious projection, filling a void in existing literature.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER I: Existence of the Astral Body long known—My first conscious projection
structure_content.summary: This chapter establishes the historical understanding of the astral body (e.g., Egyptian KA, Tibetan Bardo Thodol) and details the author's first conscious projection experience. It describes the initial sensations of catalepsy, floating, and vibration, followed by the realization of being outside the physical body, connected by an elastic-like cord, and attempts to interact with the physical world.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER II: Astral catalepsy—Types of projection—Astral somnambulism—Distant point projection—The phantom's three moving speeds—Morbidity an incentive to projection—Instantaneous astral exteriorization—An ephemeral conscious projection experience—Instantaneous projection is not uncommon—Collision may cause astral exteriorization—A projection caused by a mis-step—The fundamental law of astral projection—Intentional and unintentional projection both result from the same causes—Meaning of physical "incapacity"—Where and what is the conscious mind?—The hypnagogic state, neurosis and sleep—Sensation and emotion at different stages of exteriorization
structure_content.summary: Muldoon delves into the mechanics of astral projection, defining astral catalepsy as a rigid state of the phantom. He categorizes projections as conscious, partially conscious, or unconscious, and describes three moving speeds (natural, intermediate, supernormal). He introduces the 'Fundamental Law of Astral Projection,' stating that the subconscious Will moves the astral body when the physical is 'incapacitated' and the subconscious Will is 'possessed of the idea' to move. Factors like morbidity, sudden shock, and suppressed desire are identified as incentives for projection.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER III: Route the phantom travels in projection—Some symptoms of astral exteriorization—The astral cable—Cord-activity range—An interiorization caused by a noise—Repercussion of the astral body
structure_content.summary: This chapter details the specific route the astral phantom takes during exteriorization, which is governed by the physical body's position. It thoroughly describes the astral cable—its appearance, elasticity, and varying diameter based on distance. The concept of 'cord-activity range' is introduced, where peculiar sensations and phenomena occur. The author explains how external factors like noise, or emotional states, can cause sudden 'repercussion' (re-coincidence) of the astral body with the physical.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER IV: Typical "projection" dreams—How I discovered the cause of many falling dreams—Types of "falls" or interiorizations—The causes of the different "falls"—How to break the repercussion in a falling dream—Types of flying dreams—The flapping dream—Head-thumping dream—Dream of moving toward a phantasmal object—Dream delusions
structure_content.summary: Muldoon links various common dream types to astral body activities. He argues that falling and flying dreams, head-thumping dreams, and dreams of moving toward phantasmal objects are often direct experiences or repercussions of the astral body's movements during projection or interiorization. He provides methods, such as 'letting go' in a falling dream, to mitigate negative repercussions.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER V: Effect of instability—Eccentricities of the senses—Duplicate sense of touch—Phantom can pass through needle-points without feeling—Delusions of the senses during the hypnotic trance—Duplicate sensibility and obsession—The case of "89"—The painful bayonet case—Duplicate and shifting motivity—A "rap" produced at will, during exteriorization of motivity
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores how sensory perception and motivity behave eccentrically during astral projection, particularly within the 'cord-activity range.' It discusses 'dual astral vision' and 'duplicate sense of touch,' noting how sensations can be transferred between the physical and astral bodies. The author also presents cases of 'obsession' where astral pain persists after death, and describes an experience of producing a physical 'rap' (telekinesis) through subconscious will while projected.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER VI: The purpose of sleep—Dream control—Subjects of "nervous temperament" are best suited for psychic experiments—When outside cord-activity range the phantom is free—Prolonged projection—The projector cannot get lost—How the physical is recharged during projection—Not dead but sleeping!—The astral cable is akin to the umbilical cord
structure_content.summary: Muldoon explains sleep as a natural discoincidence of the astral body for recharging with cosmic energy, and states that 'nervous temperaments' are more prone to projection. He assures readers that a projector cannot get lost in the astral, as the subconscious Will will always pull the phantom back for physical recharging. The astral cable is analogized to an umbilical cord, symbolizing its life-sustaining connection.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER VII: Where the astral "line of force" makes contact with the bodies—Turning over in the air—The four brains of man—The pineal gland—The pituitary body—The Cosmic energy—Doctor Lindlahr's views on energy—Foods, fasting and psychic development—Fasting increases the inflow of Cosmic energy—How fasting aids astral projection—Consciousness uses up energy!
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores the contact points of the astral 'line of force' on the physical body, suggesting the medulla oblongata as the primary region. It delves into the energetic aspects of projection, discussing cosmic energy, the role of various glands (pineal, pituitary), and the views of Dr. Lindlahr on food and fasting. Muldoon posits that fasting increases the inflow of cosmic energy and aids astral projection, while conscious activity itself consumes energy.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER VIII: Consciousness during astral projection—A "dreaming-true" experience—Awakened in the astral by a "noise"—The dream world—The "dream-control" method of projection—The proper dream will always project the phantom—Summary of the dream-control method—Bringing consciousness to the dream body
structure_content.summary: The author details how consciousness can be brought to the astral body through 'dream-control.' He explains that if a dream's action corresponds to the astral phantom's movements, it can induce conscious projection. A specific 'elevator dream' method is outlined, where visualizing oneself moving upward in an elevator during sleep triggers the astral body to project. The chapter also covers how sounds can trigger awakening in the astral body, and the nature of the 'dream world' as the astral plane.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER IX: The factors which stimulate the subconscious Will to action—How I discovered that "desire" is an activating factor—The action of the unconscious phantom is governed by the "stress"—Sexual desire is a negative factor—Phantom projects more easily to a familiar place—Projecting from an unfamiliar to a familiar place—Phantoms of the dead are often dominated by the "stress" of desire or habit—The unconscious phantom sometimes moves material objects—A "haunter" under the stress of a desirable habit—An early morning "haunter"—The factor "enervation"
structure_content.summary: This chapter identifies the 'stress of expression' from deep-rooted desires, habits, and dreams as the primary motivator for the subconscious Will to project the astral body. It explains how suppressed desires, particularly thirst, are powerful activating factors, while sexual desire is a negative one. The author notes that phantoms, including those of the dead, are governed by these 'stresses,' which can lead to actions like haunting or moving physical objects.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER X: Determining the proper "stress" to use in developing—Incapacity—the fundamental difference between astral projection and physical somnambulism—An astral projection which was caused by thirst—A physical somnambulation which was caused by thirst—How I discovered that incapacity is an important factor—Some positive minor factors—Repercussion noises—"Light" a negative factor—An interiorization caused by excess light—Telepathic repercussion
structure_content.summary: Muldoon guides the reader in selecting the most effective 'stress' for projection, recommending 'thirst' due to its ease of instigation and strong motivational power. He elaborates on 'incapacity' as the key differentiator between astral projection and physical somnambulism, achieved by slowing the heart rate. Minor factors like temperature and external noises are discussed, with 'light' and certain sounds identified as negative factors that can cause interiorization or repercussion.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XI: How to induce "incapacity"—Developing a consciousness of Self—Dynamization of projection—What is "will"?—Typical dreams of projection—How to instil the stress of routine—How to instil the stress of thirst—Projecting to water
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides detailed exercises to induce physical 'incapacity,' primarily through controlled relaxation and slowing of the heart rate. It introduces techniques for developing 'consciousness of Self' by intense self-observation, even to the point of deluding the mind into believing one's reflection is the true self. The concept of 'dynamization of projection'—saturating the mind with the desire and knowledge of astral projection—is presented as a method to instil a powerful 'stress' that aids projection, exemplified by an experience of projecting to a spring after inducing thirst.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XII: Conscious projection is rare—The passive Will—Inducing projection by the passive Will method—The results produced by dynamization of projection—Some typical projections
structure_content.summary: Muldoon highlights the rarity of fully conscious astral projection from beginning to end, noting that most accounts involve consciousness arising after the projection has already occurred. He introduces the 'Passive Will' method, where intense, imaginative desires cultivated in a drowsy, conscious state at night can powerfully influence the subconscious mind to induce projection. The chapter details typical projection experiences, including distant travel and interactions, and the outcomes of 'dynamization of projection.'

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XIII: The crypto-conscious mind—Crypto-conscious manifestations often credited to phantoms of the dead—The various ways in which the mind functions—A superconscious projection—Automatic projection—A horrible experience—Why victims of violent death re-enact their death in the astral body—The case of Irene
structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces the 'crypto-conscious mind' as a reasoning, directing aspect of the unconscious Will that controls astral projections. It distinguishes its actions from mere subconscious impulses and describes 'automatic projections' where this mind takes independent control. The author recounts a 'horrible experience' of being electrocuted and consciously projected, illustrating how intense trauma can cause victims of violent death to re-enact their demise in the astral body, often leading to an 'earthbound' state.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XIV: The crypto-conscious mind and telekinesis—An astral projection in which I moved a physical object—"Raps" produced during a dream—The sex of the astral body—Inter-relation of the physical and astral counterparts—Composition of the astral body—Calculated weight of the astral body—The clothing of the phantom—"As a man thinketh"—Purgatory—Thought sustains the astral body—Earthbound phantoms not numerous—An encounter with an astral fiend
structure_content.summary: Muldoon explores the crypto-conscious mind's role in telekinesis, recounting an instance where he indirectly moved a physical object during an astral projection, and how 'raps' can be produced. He clarifies that the astral body retains sexual organs and is an exact duplicate of the physical, while its composition is of subtle, vibrating matter, with a calculated weight of approximately 2.5 oz. The chapter explains how 'thought sustains the astral body' and how earthbound phantoms (often under 'stress') create their own environment and experiences.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XV: Obsession—The Akashic Records—Enacting future events in the dream body—Many clairvoyant dreams are mistaken for astral projections—Dream consciousness is not the real consciousness—Death is merely a permanent projection
structure_content.summary: This chapter discusses obsession, attributing it to earthbound phantoms under 'stress' or to the individual's own mind. It delves into the concept of 'Akashic Records' as impressions in the 'Universal Ether' that store all past events. The author describes experiences of enacting future events in dream-projections, emphasizing that many seemingly clairvoyant dreams are not true astral projections, and concludes that death is essentially a permanent astral projection.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER XVI: Projection during the sleep of anaesthesia—A peculiar dream—There may be other methods—A prophecy—All possess the powers of projection—Concerning morals—The demon theory—Conclusion
structure_content.summary: Muldoon examines astral projection during anesthesia, citing cases where subjects observed their physical bodies. He discusses a 'peculiar dream' involving an astral cord likened to a clothesline, leading back to the physical body. The chapter offers a prophecy of future physical travel through space and asserts that all individuals possess the latent power of projection. It touches on moral considerations, linking negative thoughts to hostile astral experiences, and addresses the 'demon theory' as a common but often misguided objection to occult phenomena.

key_concepts.definition: The ethereal counterpart of the physical body, the true seat of consciousness and the vehicle of the soul. It is an exact duplicate of the physical form, composed of fine ethereal matter that vibrates at higher rates, capable of detaching from the physical body.

The conscious or unconscious separation of the astral body from the physical body. It can be involuntary (during sleep, trance, shock) or voluntary (willed by the subject), allowing the conscious entity to perceive and interact with the astral plane.

An elastic, vital thread connecting the astral body to the physical body during projection. Its integrity is crucial; severance results in death. It conducts sense currents and motivity, and its tension varies with the distance of separation.

The proximate distance from the physical body (approximately 3-15 feet) where the astral cable exhibits dynamic activity, influencing sensations, causing instability in the phantom, and affecting the ease of movement and interiorization.

A state of profound passivity in the physical body, typically induced by slowing the heart rate, enervation, or sedative illness. This condition makes the physical body less responsive to the subconscious Will, thereby enabling the astral body to separate more easily.

An intensified impulse or urge, stemming from deep-rooted desires, habits, or mental impressions, that accumulates in the subconscious mind. This 'stress' acts as a potent suggestion, compelling the subconscious Will to move the astral body to act out or appease the underlying impulse.

The innate, often unrecognized, power within individuals that directs bodily movements and actions. In the context of astral projection, it is the primary force that moves the astral body, especially when influenced by strong 'stress' and physical 'incapacity.'

A reasoning, analyzing, and directing department of the unconscious mind that possesses its own Will. It can independently control the astral body's movements during projection, respond to strong subconscious 'stress,' and even produce physical phenomena like telekinesis.

A practical technique for inducing conscious astral projection by constructing a vivid, enjoyable 'aviation type' dream (e.g., flying, rising in an elevator) before sleep. The dream's action, when aligned with the phantom's natural movements, serves as a powerful suggestion to the subconscious Will to project the astral body.

A technique for inducing projection by cultivating an intense, imaginative desire to project while in a drowsy, conscious state at night. This 'Passive Will' (also 'Imaginative Will') strongly impresses the subconscious mind, leading to projection without active, forceful conscious effort.

The sudden, often violent and unpleasant, re-coincidence of the astral body with the physical body. It can be triggered by external noises, strong emotions (especially fear), or the awakening of consciousness during an unconscious projection, often accompanied by a physical jolt or pain.

A state of physical weakness, fatigue, or lack of neuric (cosmic) energy, which Muldoon asserts is a positive factor for astral projection as it reduces the physical body's resistance and enhances the astral body's ability to detach and recharge.

practical_system.description: The system for inducing conscious astral projection relies on a two-pronged approach: creating physical 'incapacity' and instilling a powerful 'stress of expression' in the subconscious mind. 'Incapacity' is achieved by physiological manipulation (e.g., slowing heart rate, deep breathing exercises) to render the physical body unusually passive, as it normally would be during deep sleep or illness. 'Stress of expression' is cultivated through intense mental concentration on a desired projection, often via a 'dream-control' method (visualizing a specific, enjoyable astral action before sleep) or by suppressing a strong bodily desire like thirst, which then compels the subconscious Will to project. The 'crypto-conscious mind,' a reasoning faculty of the unconscious, then takes control, executing the projection based on these imprinted 'suggestions.' Emotional control and a calm mental state are crucial during the initial stages of projection and interiorization to prevent negative repercussions.
tools: Glass of cold water (for visualization in thirst stress)
Alarm clock (to establish habit of awakening at specific times for Passive Will method)
Minimal clothing and a quiet, dimly lit sleeping environment (to reduce distractions and aid detachment)
rituals: Dream-Control Method: Consistently construct and visualize an 'aviation type' dream (e.g., rising in an elevator, flying) before falling asleep, aiming for the dream action to correspond with the desired astral body movement. Suggest awakening at a specific point in the dream-locale.

Thirst Stress Method: Deprive oneself of liquids for a significant period before retiring. Aggravate the desire by thinking of water, gazing at it, and even swallowing a small amount of salt. Then, visualize the astral body traveling to a water source to appease this intensified desire while falling asleep.

Incapacity Induction (Heart Control): Assume a comfortable horizontal position, preferably on the back. Perform deep breathing exercises to relax the solar plexus. Systematically tense and relax muscle groups from head to toe. Then, concentrate on the heart's pulsations and mentally instruct the heart to slow its beat, practicing until a consciously controlled reduction in pulse rate is achieved.

Consciousness of Self Exercise: Sit facing a mirror and intensely scrutinize one's reflection, attempting to believe that the reflection is the 'real you' and not merely an image. Try to go to sleep with this belief imprinted on the mind to influence subconscious self-perception.

Passive Will Method: During nocturnal awakenings (e.g., 2 AM), consciously but drowsily fix the mind with intense desire and knowledge of astral projection, visualizing 'impossible' projection scenarios as perfectly reasonable. Go back to sleep with this dominating imaginative Will.

relevant_quotes.text: "In my opinion, it is this . . . notion of a subtle body, which for so many centuries has played the dominant r8le in the traditional psychology of both the East and the West, that is most deserving of being retried, reviewed and revised ; to serve as a working hypothesis to co-ordinate and explain a very large number of these puzzling psychical phenomena ."
"These self-projections represent the most extraordinary achievements of the human will, and, are perhaps acts which a man might perform equally well before and after death ."

I have given the specific methods for bringing about the projection of the astral body, as I know them, and I am willing to have the truth of my statements judged squarely by the results' obtained through the practice of these methods. You want proof, and I say you can have itbut you must experience it. You want to know how you can experience it, and I tell you how to go about it . I can do no more.

The only difference between astral projection and death is that the cord is intact in the former case, and severed in the latter . This cord—the " Silver Cord " spoken of in Ecclesiastes—is elastic, and capable of great extension . It constitutes the essential link between the two bodies .

IF THE SUBCONSCIOUS WILL BECOMES POSSESSED OF THE IDEA TO MOVE THE BODY (COINCIDING BODIES) AND THE PHYSICAL BODY IS INCAPACITATED, THE SUBCONSCIOUS WILL MOVES THE ASTRAL BODY INDEPENDENT OF THE PHYSICAL .

"The statements of the 'communicators' as to what occurs on the physical side may be put in brief general terms as follows . We all have bodies composed of ' luminiferous ether' enclosed in our flesh and blood bodies . The relation of Mrs . Piper's etherial body to the etherial world, in which the 'communicators' claim to dwell, is such that a special store of peculiar energy is accumulated in connection with her organism, and this appears to them as ' a light .' . . . " etc .
EMOTIONS OF UNPLEASANTNESS, ALARM, FEAR, ETC ., ARE VERITABLE SUGGESTIONS TO THE SUBCON SCIOUS WILL, THAT THE SUBJECT WISHES TO BE NORMAL, OR PHYSICALLY CORRECT .
When the action of self, in the dream, corresponds to the action of the astral phantom, the dream will cause the phantom actually to exteriorize .

" If you strike a magnet of this type a sharp blow with a hammer, or heat it red-hot and allow it to become cool again, it will be found to have lost its magnetism . What has happened ? Probably the molecules of iron, which before had been uniform, in their polarity, are now 'pointing' in all directions, and hence the energy which formerly played on or through the bar of iron, in one continuous unbroken stream, is now broken up, and playing in a thousand different directions . Hence the iron will no longer be a magnet . "

The astral body does not separate from the physical body at night, during sleep, because it has too much energy—but because it has not enough ; that is the reason why we go to sleep . If it were strength of Will and accumulation of energy which caused projection of the astral body, the sick person would be unable to project ; but this is precisely the opposite of the known facts . Now I have the greatest of respect for all of my contemporaries in this field, but I believe that their theories of " good health " and " accumulation of energy " are honeycombed with inconsistencies ; and I am dogmatic in my " subconscious stress " theory.

The greatest objection which I have heard advanced against the practice of astral body projection is that, while the phantom is exteriorized from the body, a foreign astral entity might be able to inhabit the physical mechanism, and prevent the real owner (the projector) from getting back into his own body again !

I am firmly convinced, for my part, that almost any two people can produce this repercussion, by exactly as I have said ; and if the subject, attempting astral projection, wishes to have some sympathetic friend try to assist him, I believe that this would be the best possible exercise to attempt first, as it “ registers,” we might say, when the minds are in attunement, and thus the two are able to find the route to more extensive experiments .

No longer will you be forced to accept theories . No longer will you be forced to base your belief in immortality upon the word of the Medium, the Pastor, or the Holy Books, for you will have the proof for yourself—as sure and as self-evident as the fact that you are physically alive .

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant within Western Esotericism and Occultism as it provides a rare, detailed, and purportedly first-hand account of the mechanics of conscious astral projection. It departs from much theoretical literature by focusing on operative methods, drawing parallels with other traditions (e.g., Yoga, Tibetan Book of the Dead), and attempting to ground these phenomena in a quasi-scientific framework. Its discussion of 'incapacity,' 'stress,' and the 'crypto-conscious mind' offers a unique perspective on controlling subconscious processes for OOBE. The historical context and comparisons with contemporary psychic research (e.g., S.P.R., Oliver Fox, Durville) position it as a significant contribution to the early 20th-century occult revival, particularly regarding practical self-initiation into astral work.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is 'psychic students' and 'students of the occult' who are already predisposed to believe in supernormal phenomena and are seeking practical, operative methods for astral projection. The author explicitly states it is not for 'Materialists' or 'sceptics' seeking conventional objective proof. Warnings are given against practice by those who are neurotic, fearful, or susceptible to obsession, suggesting a need for mental and emotional stability or a particular temperament. It also appeals to those interested in the 'how' rather than just the 'what' of astral experiences.
